text: hi this is Suzanne Craig reporting for
the New York Times it's November and on
Wall Street that means just one thing
we're about one month away from when
bonuses will be handed out it's been a
rough few years on Wall Street and there
hasn't been a lot of money going around
but a new survey suggests that this year
but bonuses will actually be up across
the board about 5% it's some of the main
firms that may be down a little bit be
at City or Morgan Stanley but asset
managers and other areas may actually
see it tick up I would say it's keeping
within trends it's higher than it would
have been in 2003 for but lower than it
was in two thousand six and seven so
we've have been on a roller coaster ride
where we've come out some this is no
mean by any means the highest it's ever
been as well below 0 six no seven but I
think as we said earlier the populace in
America millions is too much let alone
multi millions there's going to be a few
wrinkles this year when compensation is
handed out one of the main ones is that
the ratio of stock and cash will change
during the boom years executives tended
to get a lot of cash and very little
stock or less stock anyways and this
year we're going to see more stock the
reason is is that firms are trying to
align the employees with the performance
of the firm so if it does well they do
well and if it doesn't they don't do
well the biggest change in pay is not
that the weave rescinded the competitive
market is that the pay is delivered much
further in the future and your linked
much closer the firm actually succeeding
the other thing is as salaries have come
up is a part of the total pave Wall
Street salaries were very low for very
long time salaries of increase you know
from 200 and some thousand for senior
people to four or five hundred thousand
for senior people the credit crisis may
be over and many of the firms have paid
back the emergency government money that
they were given but still like
regulators will be paying a lot of
attention to what's handed out this year
I think the average wall street person
now is acutely focused on risk and
chances because a screw-up clearly will
be very
harshly punished career pay reputation
whatever so I think the regulator's at
least for the time being have got
everybody's attention for Main Street I
think the surprise in all of us is
pretty evident that just two years after
Wall Street pushed the financial system
almost to the brink of collapse wall
street bonuses are back and they're big
they may not be quite as big as they
were during the heydays but they're
certainly going to be sizable this year
